Authors:
Davi Mesquita Macedo, Olinto Liparini Pereira, Bevan S
Weir, Robert W. Barreto, Braz Tavares Hora Junior
Title:
Mycobiota of Tradescantia fluminensis Mycobiota of the weed
Tradescantia fluminensis in its native range in Brazil with particular
reference to classical biological control
Keywords:
Biological invasions, mycology, plant pathogen,
taxonomy
Abstract:
Tradescantia fluminensis [Commelinaceae], (common name
wandering Jew) is a native Brazilian herbaceous plant which has been
introduced to be used as an ornamental in many warm areas of the world.
In New Zealand and other countries it has become an aggressive invader
of natural ecosystems, causing serious environmental disturbances and
leading to serious threats to biodiversity. It has been targeted in a
classical biological control program involving the assessment and
evaluation of several pathogens and insects natural enemies collected in
Brazil for introduction into New Zealand. The surveys conducted along
several years yielded seven pathogenic fungi in association with T.
fluminensis and related species including three species described herein
as new to science: Ceratobasidium tradescantiae sp. nov. (web blight),
Colletotrichum riograndense sp. nov. (anthracnose) and Kordyana
brasiliensis sp. nov. (white smut). Additionally the following species
were also collected on this host: Cercospora apii (leaf spot),
Rhizoctonia solani (leaf blight), Sclerotium rolfsii (crown rot) and
Uromyces commelinae (rust). Preliminary observations of damage in the
field and expected host-range suggest that K. brasiliensis and U.
commelinae have the highest potential for use as classical biological
control agents.
